using the eyes of the fourth stage to see the form of the fifth stage,

This should be understood according to the appropriate [stage].
As explained, the noble ones are born in the first dhyÄna.
In the same way, one is born in the second, third, and fourth dhyÄnas.
Each should be explained in detail according to the corresponding characteristics.
Here, eye consciousness depends on the eyes of its own stage.
It can have two kinds when taking form of a lower stage as its object,
namely excluding the defiled [eye consciousness].
When taking form of its own stage as its object, it can have three kinds.
If it depends on the eyes of a higher stage, it is only unobstructed indeterminate.
The wholesome and defiled eye consciousness can only occur in its own stage.
Because of this, it is definitely bound to the stage of birth.
The discriminating mental consciousness of the wholesome [realm] can take as its object all stages, whether above, below, or its own.
The defiled discriminating mental consciousness can only take as its object its own stage and higher stages.
The unobstructed indeterminate discriminating mental consciousness can only take as its object its own stage and lower stages.
The wholesome and defiled discriminating mental consciousness born in its own stage and lower stages can occur.
It does not occur when born in a higher stage.
The unobstructed indeterminate discriminating mental consciousness only occurs when born in its own stage.
Because of this, it is definitely bound to the stage of birth.
The subsequent arising of visual consciousness is the conceptual consciousness, not just a single arising.
Even if it passes through many lives, it can still arise in dependence on the seen form.
Question: What is the reason that one born in the last three meditations
can manifest the visual consciousness of the first meditation?
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Who says that one born in the last three meditations can manifest the visual consciousness, etc., of the first meditation?
In the last three meditations, there are visual consciousnesses, etc., that depend on faculties of their own level and perceive objects of their own level.
If it were not so,
how could one born above make skillful efforts
to bring the visual consciousness, etc., of the first meditation into the present?
The judges say:
They should not say this.
They should say:
The last three meditations do not have visual consciousness, etc.
Why is this?
Because they are without applied thought and sustained thought.
Because the five consciousnesses of the eye, etc., always arise in association with applied thought and sustained thought.
Question: What is the reason that one born in the last three meditations
They do not cause the eye consciousnesses, etc. of the desire realm to appear.
But they only give rise to the consciousnesses of the first meditative absorption.
There is an explanation that says:
Because the desire realm is inferior, when one is born in a superior realm,
one does not wish to cause the eye consciousnesses, etc. of that realm to appear.
There is another explanation that says:
Because the realms are different.
The eye consciousnesses, etc. of the desire realm are not of the same realm as the faculties of the higher realms.
The consciousnesses of the first meditative absorption are not of the same realm as the faculties of the higher realms,
but because they are of the same realm, they can also arise in dependence on those faculties.
There is another explanation that says:
Because the eye consciousnesses, etc. of the desire realm are not the results of cultivation or the results of supernormal powers,
they cannot appear in dependence on the faculties of the higher realms.
Because the eye consciousnesses, etc. of the first meditative absorption are the results of cultivation and the results of supernormal powers,
they can appear in dependence on the faculties of the higher realms.
There is another explanation that says:
Because the eye consciousnesses, etc. of the desire realm are not the realm of concentration, are not the stage of cultivation,
and are not the stage of freedom from passion,
they cannot appear in dependence on the faculties of the higher realms.
The eye consciousness and so on of the first trance state are the realm of concentration, the stage of cultivation, and the stage of separation from defilements.
Therefore, the consciousnesses of the upper stages can also manifest based on the faculties of the lower stages.
For these and other various reasons,
when one is born in the latter three trance states, one can give rise to the eye consciousnesses and so on of the first trance state, but not the desire realm.
Just as the eye consciousnesses of the various stages are based on the faculties of the various stages and perceive the forms of the various stages,
the three kinds of conceptualization in the guiding mental consciousness are present in varying degrees.
The ear consciousnesses and so on should be understood in the same way.
Question: If one possesses the eye element, does one also possess the form element?
Answer: If one possesses the eye element, one also possesses the form element.
There are those who possess the form element but do not possess the eye element.
Namely, those born in the desire realm who have not yet obtained the eye,
or have obtained it but lost it.
Those who have not yet obtained the eye
refer to those in the kalala and other stages, as well as those born blind.
Those who have obtained it but lost it
refer to those who have obtained the eye but it has become rotten,
or been plucked out, eaten by worms,
or destroyed by other conditions.
Question: Do those who have attained the eye element also have the eye-consciousness element?
Answer: Four sentences should be made.
There are those who have attained the eye element but have not attained the eye-consciousness element.
Namely, those born in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions.
The eye-consciousness element is not presently manifest.
There are those who have attained the eye-consciousness element but have not attained the eye element.
Namely, those born in the desire realm who have not yet attained the eye or have lost it after attaining it.
There are those who have attained the eye element and have also attained the eye-consciousness element.
Namely, those born in the desire realm who have attained the eye and have not lost it.
Or those born in the first meditative absorption.
Or those born in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions for whom the eye-consciousness element is presently manifest.
There are those who have not attained the eye element.
And have also not attained the eye-consciousness element.
Namely, those born in the formless realm.
Question: Do those who have attained the form element also have the eye-consciousness element?
Answer: If one has attained the eye-consciousness element,
One has also attained the form element.
There are those who possess the form realm but do not possess the eye consciousness realm.
Namely, those born in the second, third, and fourth meditative absorptions.
The eye consciousness realm is not presently manifest.
Question: If one does not possess the eye realm, does one also not possess the form realm?
Answer: If one does not possess the form realm,
one also does not possess the eye realm.
There are those who do not possess the eye realm but do not not possess the form realm.
Namely, those born in the desire realm who have not yet obtained the eyes or have lost them.
Question: Those who do not possess the eye realm,
do they also not possess the eye consciousness realm?
Answer: Four sentences should be made.
There are those who do not possess the eye realm but do not not possess the eye consciousness realm.
Namely, those born in the desire realm who have not yet obtained the eyes,
or have lost them.
There are those who do not possess the eye consciousness realm but do not not possess the eye realm.
Namely, those born in the second, third, and fourth meditative absorptions whose eye consciousness realm is not presently manifest.
There are those who do not possess the eye realm,
One who does not possess the eye consciousness element also does not possess the eye element.
Namely, one born in the formless realm.
There is one who does not possess the eye element but also does not not possess the eye consciousness element.
Namely, one born in the desire realm who has obtained the eye and not lost it.
Or one born in the first meditative absorption.
Or one born in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions for whom the eye consciousness element is presently manifest.
Question: Those who do not possess the form element,
do they also not possess the eye consciousness element?
Answer: If one does not possess the form element,
one also does not possess the eye consciousness element.
There are those who do not possess the eye consciousness element but do not not possess the form element.
Namely, those born in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions for whom the eye consciousness element is not presently manifest.
Question: Those who do not possess the eye element,
do they also obtain possession of the form element?
Answer: If the form element does not possess,
the eye element also obtains possession.
There are those who do not possess the eye element but obtain possession, but not the form element.
It means gradually obtaining the eye element when born in the desire realm.
Question: Do all those who obtain the accomplishment of the eye element also obtain the accomplishment of the eye consciousness element?
Answer: Four sentences should be made.
There is the eye element that is obtained without accomplishment, but not the eye consciousness element.
It means dying in the formless realm and being born in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions,
or being born in the desire realm and gradually obtaining the eye element.ğŸ”½There is the eye consciousness element that is obtained without accomplishment,
but not the eye element.
It means the eye consciousness element appearing in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions,
or dying from there and being born in the desire realm or the first meditative absorption.
There is the eye element that is obtained without accomplishment,
and also the eye consciousness element.
It means dying in the formless realm and being born in the desire realm or the first meditative absorption.
There is the eye element that is not obtained without accomplishment, and also not the eye consciousness element.
It means excluding the previous characteristics.
Question: Do all those who obtain the accomplishment of the form element also obtain the accomplishment of the eye consciousness element?
The answer is: four sentences should be made.
There is form that is not yet accomplished,
but the eye consciousness element is accomplished and obtained.
This refers to one who dies in the formless realm and is reborn in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions.
There is the eye consciousness element that is not yet accomplished, but is accomplished and obtained, and the form element is not so.
This refers to one who is reborn in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions, and the eye consciousness element is present.
Or one who dies in those realms and is reborn in the desire realm or the first meditative absorption.
There is form that is not yet accomplished,
but the eye consciousness element is accomplished and obtained.
This refers to one who dies in the formless realm and is reborn in the desire realm or the first meditative absorption.
There is form that is not not yet accomplished,
but the eye consciousness element is not accomplished and obtained.
This refers to excluding the above characteristics.
Question: Those who accomplish the eye element,
do they also accomplish and obtain the form element?
Answer: Four sentences should be made.
There is the eye element that is accomplished,
but the form element is not yet accomplished and obtained.
This refers to one who is born in the desire realm, has already obtained the eye, but has lost it.
Those in the form realm possess it.
One may not possess the eye faculty but possess the eye element.
This refers to one in the desire realm without eyes who dies and is reborn in the formless realm.
One may possess the eye element and acquire it, and also possess the form realm.
This refers to one in the desire realm with eyes who dies and is reborn in the formless realm.
Or one in the form realm who dies and is reborn in the formless realm.
One may neither possess the eye element nor acquire it, nor possess the form realm.
This refers to excluding the above cases.
Question: Do those who possess the eye element and acquire it also possess the eye consciousness element?
Answer: One should make four alternatives.
One may possess the eye element and acquire it, but not possess the eye consciousness element.
This refers to one born in the desire realm who has already obtained eyes but has lost them.
Or one who dies in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions and is reborn in the formless realm.
One may possess the eye consciousness element and acquire it, but not possess the eye element.
This refers to one in the desire realm without eyes who dies and is reborn in the formless realm.
Or, having died in the first dhyÄna of the desire realm, one is born in the second, third, or fourth dhyÄna, or one's eye consciousness is present there and is eliminated.
There are those who both acquire and do not acquire the eye element, and also the eye consciousness element.
This refers to those in the desire realm who die and are reborn in the formless realm.
Or those who die in the first dhyÄna and are reborn in the formless realm.
There are those who neither acquire nor do not acquire the eye element, and also not the eye consciousness element.
This refers to excluding the above characteristics.
Question: Do those who acquire and do not acquire the form realm also acquire and do not acquire the eye consciousness element?
Answer: One should make four alternatives.
There are those who acquire and do not acquire the form realm but not the eye consciousness element.
This refers to those who die in the second, third, or fourth dhyÄna and are reborn in the formless realm.
There are those who acquire and do not acquire the eye consciousness element but not the form realm.
This refers to those who die in the desire realm or the first dhyÄna.
And are reborn in the second, third, or fourth dhyÄna.
Or one's eye consciousness is present there and is eliminated.
There are those who both obtain and do not obtain the eye consciousness element in the form realm.
This refers to those who die in the desire realm or first dhyÄna and are reborn in the formless realm.
There are those who neither obtain nor do not obtain the eye consciousness element in the form realm.
This refers to those who are excluded from the above.
Just as the eye element, form element, and eye consciousness element are mutually related in twelve treatises, so are the ear element, sound element, and ear consciousness element mutually related.
Up to the mind element, dharma element, and mind consciousness element are mutually related.
Each should also have twelve treatises.
This is said to be the same part corresponding to the same part.
If it is the different part corresponding to the different part,
it should be said like this.
The eye element, form element, and eye consciousness element have five kinds of three treatises.
The ear element, sound element, and ear consciousness element have four kinds of three treatises.
The nose element, smell element, and nose consciousness element have three kinds of three treatises.
The tongue element, taste element, and tongue consciousness element have two kinds of three treatises.
The body element, the tangible element, and the body consciousness element have one kind of three treatises.
In this way, each one should be understood according to its corresponding characteristics.
The twelve sense bases are:

The eye sense base, the form sense base, the ear sense base, the sound sense base, the nose sense base, the smell sense base, the tongue sense base, the taste sense base, the body sense base, the tangible sense base, the mind sense base, and the dharma sense base.
Why did he compose this treatise?
The answer is: in order to extensively analyze the meaning of the sutras.
As the sutras say:
There was a Brahmin named Jatila
who came to where the Buddha was.
Having arrived, he bowed at the World-Honored One's feet,
joined his palms in respect, greeted the Buddha, and then sat to one side.
He said to the Buddha:
Venerable Gautama,
you always teach the assembly about everything.
What is meant by everything?
Up to what point is the word 'everything' established?
The Buddha told the Brahmin Jatila:
I say that everything refers to the twelve sense bases,
namely the eye sense base up to the dharma sense base.
The Tathagata establishes everything up to this point.
If there are Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, etc. who say like this:
I can abandon all that is spoken by the Buddha,
and separately establish the term 'all' again.
They only have words but no real meaning.
If they are asked back, they will not be able to understand.
Later, when they think about it themselves, they will become confused.
Why is it so?
Because it is not their realm.
Although the sÅ«tra says this, it does not distinguish its meaning.
The sÅ«tra is the fundamental basis of this treatise.
Since he did not speak of it, he now wishes to speak of it.
Therefore, this treatise is composed.
If it is said like this:
The term 'all' refers to the eighteen elements.
Some say:
The term 'all' refers to the five aggregates and the unconditioned.
Some say:
The term 'all' refers to the four truths and the non-analytical cessation of space.
Some say:
The term 'all' refers to name and form.
How can it be that such statements are mere words without real meaning? Answer: Here, the meaning of negation does not negate the text.
It only negates the establishment of meaning.
It does not negate the establishment of the text.
The Buddha's intention is to say:
The natures of all dharmas are all included within these twelve sense bases.
If there is someone who says:
I can establish that there are other dharmas apart from these,
which are not included within these twelve sense bases.
That person only has words but no real meaning.
It is not the Buddha's intention to say that apart from the twelve sense bases there are no dharma gates such as name and form.
However, the teaching of the twelve sense bases spoken by the Buddha is the most supreme and wonderful, not other dharma gates.
Question: Why is this teaching the most supreme and wonderful?
Answer: This is because it is the middle way, encompassing all dharmas.
Although the teaching of the eighteen elements encompasses all dharmas,
it is extensive and difficult to accept and uphold.
The teaching of the five aggregates is not only difficult to understand due to its brevity,
but it also cannot encompass all dharmas.
Because the three unconditioned dharmas are not included in the aggregates.
Only the Buddha's teaching of the twelve sense bases includes all dharmas.
It is neither extensive nor concise.
Therefore, it is said to be the most excellent and sublime.
Therefore, it is said:
If one wishes to contemplate the nature and characteristics of all dharmas,
one should rely on the teaching of the twelve sense bases.
If one contemplates the nature and characteristics of all dharmas based on the teaching of the twelve sense bases,
one will give rise to the light of wisdom of the twelve kinds of suchness.
And it will manifest the twelve images of true meaning.
It is like a person polishing twelve mirrors and hanging them in all directions.
If one enters there, one will manifest the twelve images of one's own body.
In each sentient being's body, the twelve sense bases can be obtained. If there are twelve sense bases in one body,
how are the twelve sense bases established?
The answer is: because of their different natures and functions.
Although the twelve sense bases are in one body,
However, the twelve kinds of intrinsic natures and functions are different from each other, so they are not mixed with each other.
It is like in one room there are twelve people with different skills.
Although they are in the same room, there are twelve intrinsic natures and functions.
Furthermore, the twelve sense bases are established for two reasons.
First, by the basis,
which are the six such as the eye.
Second, by the objects,
which are the six such as form.
Furthermore, the twelve sense bases are established for three reasons.
First, by the intrinsic nature.
Second, by the basis.
Third, by the objects.
As for the intrinsic nature,
it refers to establishing the sense base of the eye up to the sense base of dharmas.
As for the basis,
it refers to establishing the sense base of the eye up to the sense base of the mind.
As for the objects,
it refers to establishing the sense base of form up to the sense base of dharmas.
This is called the intrinsic nature, substance, essence, aspect, and original nature of the sense bases.
The intrinsic nature of the sense bases has been explained.
The reason will now be explained.
Question: Why are they called sense bases?
What is the meaning of sphere?

The answer is: the meaning of birth gate, the meaning of birth path, the meaning of storehouse, the meaning of granary, the meaning of sutra, the meaning of killing place, the meaning of field, the meaning of pond, the meaning of stream, the meaning of ocean, the meaning of white, the meaning of pure is the meaning of sphere should be known.
Among them, the meaning of birth gate is the meaning of sphere.
Like various things are produced in a city or town.
By this, the bodies of sentient beings are nourished.
In the same way, various mental factors are produced internally in the basis and the object.
By this, the continuity of defilement and purity is nourished.
The meaning of birth path is the meaning of sphere.
Like various things are produced through a road.
By this, the bodies of sentient beings are nourished.
In the same way, various mental factors are produced internally in the basis and the object.
By this, the continuity of defilement and purity is nourished.
The meaning of storehouse is the meaning of sphere.
Like gold, silver, and other treasures are accumulated in a treasury.
In the same way, various mental factors are accumulated internally in the basis and the object.
The meaning of granary is the meaning of place.
Just as in a granary there are various grains such as rice and wheat accumulated.
In the same way, in the basis and the object, there are various mental factors accumulated.
The meaning of sÅ«tra is the meaning of place.
Just as on a woven sÅ«tra various threads are arranged.
In the same way, on the basis and the object,
various mental factors are arranged.
The meaning of killing place is the meaning of place.
Just as on a battlefield hundreds of thousands of heads are cut off and fall to the ground.
In the same way, in the basis and the object, there are innumerable kinds of mental factors.
They are destroyed by impermanence.
The meaning of field is the meaning of place.
Just as in a field various seedlings grow,
in the same way, in the basis and the object, various mental factors grow.
The meaning of pond is the meaning of place.
As there is a question:
From what pond does the water come out? What place is not blocked?
Where does it include the world? Suffering, happiness, and so forth are all exhausted.
The World-Honored One said:
Eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, and all other faculties,
This includes name and form, leaving nothing out.
Water flows from this pond, this place is not accessible,
This place includes the world, suffering, happiness, and so forth are all exhausted.
The meaning of a place is the meaning of a flow.
As there is a question:
How can one control the flow of all places?
If it has already flowed from there, who can block it again?
The World-Honored One said:
Right mindfulness can control the flow of all places.
If it has already flowed from there, pure wisdom can block it.
The meaning of a place is the meaning of an ocean.
As the World-Honored One said:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that all sentient beings take the eyes as their ocean.
The present forms are their waves.
Those who restrain themselves from the waves of forms can cross the ocean of the eyes.
One can avoid the various dangers such as whirlpools and rÄká¹£asas.
Up to the mind and dharmas, the explanation is also like this.
The meaning of purity is the meaning of the sense bases.
It means that the sense bases such as the eye are true, clear, and pure.
This is called the gate of birth, up to the meaning of purity.
The non-Buddhist treatises call this prÄtimoká¹£a.
As the non-Buddhist ascetic MÄkandika said.
Gautama said that all prÄtimoká¹£as
come into my incantation.
The sound prÄtimoká¹£a contains two meanings.
One is the fundamental meaning.
The other is the meaning of being able to do.
Because the twelve sense bases are the foundation of the mind and mental factors, and because they can move the mind and mental factors.
The reason for establishing the names of the sense bases has been explained in general.
Now, the characteristics of each one will be explained separately.
Question: What is the sense base of the eye?
Answer: The eyes that have already seen, are now seeing, or will see forms, as well as their similar counterparts, are called the eye faculty.
The words forms that have already been seen and so on are explained as in the discussion of the elements.
Up to the mind faculty, it should be understood in the same way.
Question: What is the form faculty?
Answer: Forms that have already been seen, are now being seen, or will be seen by the eyes, as well as their similar counterparts, are called the form faculty.
The words forms that have already been seen and so on are explained as in the discussion of the elements.
Up to the dharma faculty, it should be understood in the same way.
Question: If the ten form faculties and part of the dharma faculty are all in essence form,
why is only one called the form faculty?
Answer: Only this one faculty has the gross and obvious characteristics of form, which are easy to see and understand,
therefore it is called the form faculty. The other faculties are not like this,
so they are given separate names.
Furthermore, only this one faculty is the object of the two eyes,
namely the fleshly eye and the heavenly eye, therefore it is called the form faculty.
The other faculties are not like this, so they are given separate names.
Furthermore, only this one faculty is the object of the three eyes,
Because it is the object of the flesh eye, the divine eye, and the holy wisdom eye, it is called the visible form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this, so they are given separate names. Furthermore, this is the only sense base that is the object of both eyes.
Because it is the object of the eye consciousness, it is called the visible form sense base.
Therefore the Venerable SubhÅ«ti said:
If the object of both eyes is the object of the eye consciousness, it is called the visible form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this.
Furthermore, if there is coarseness, fineness, length, shortness, here and there, and place can be understood, it is called the visible form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this, so they are not the visible form sense base.
Furthermore, if the form is large and can be accumulated and easily understood, it is called the visible form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this, so they are not the visible form sense base.
Furthermore, if it can be planted and grow and is easily understood, it is called the visible form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this, so they are not the visible form sense base. Planting and growing are common to internal and external parts.
External planting refers to when seeds are sown.
Growing refers to when sprouts emerge.
Lengthening refers to when stems, leaves, flowers, and fruits appear.
The internal division of seeds refers to the state of kalala.
Growth refers to the state of arbuda.
Lengthening refers to the states of peÅ›Ä«, ghana, praÅ›ÄkhÄ, and so on. Furthermore, if something can be designated as having a directional nature, it is called a form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this, so they are not form sense bases.
Only in the form sense base are all directional natures designated.
Not in the other sense bases.
Furthermore, if something can be designated as having the nature of yojanas, it is called a form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this, so they are not form sense bases.
Only in the form sense base are all natures of yojanas designated.
Not in the other sense bases.
Furthermore, if something can cover and conceal other form dharmas,
like a hat or cap, it is called a form sense base.
The other sense bases are not like this, so they are not form sense bases.
Only the form sense base can universally cover and conceal other form dharmas.
Not the other sense bases.
Furthermore, if a sense base possesses both shape and color, it is called a form sense base.
Other places are not like this, and therefore are not the form element.
Moreover, if a place contains twenty kinds of form or twenty-one, it is called the form element.
Other places are not like this, and therefore are not the form element.
Why is it called the element of touch?ğŸ”½Is it called the element of touch because it is touchable?
Is it called the element of touch because its substance is touch?
Is it called the element of touch because it is the object of touch?
If so, what is wrong?
All three are faulty.
Why is this?
If it is called the element of touch because it is touchable,
atoms do not touch each other.
How can the element of touch be touchable?
If it is called the element of touch because its substance is touch,
the primary elements and derivative form are not by nature touch.
How can the element of touch be touch?
If it is called the element of touch because it is the object of touch,
it is also the object of other mental activities.
How can it be said that it is only the object of touch?
The correct answer is: it is called the tangible sense base because it is tangible.
Question: If the ultimate atoms do not touch each other,
how can the tangible sense base be tangible?
Answer: This is spoken of in terms of conventional truth, not in terms of ultimate truth.
The world commonly says that what is perceived by the eyes is visible,
what is perceived by the ears is audible,ğŸ”½what is perceived by the nose is olfactory,
what is perceived by the tongue is gustatory,
and what is perceived by the body is tangible.
What is perceived by the mind is knowable.
Therefore, because it is tangible, it is called the tangible sense base.
Moreover, it is called the tangible sense base because it is the condition for the arising of bodily consciousness.
As a scripture says:
Bodily contact serves as a condition for the arising of bodily consciousness.
This is because it is the ultimate truth of the mind that discriminates objects.
The object of this [consciousness] is called the tangible sense base.
Moreover, this is called the tangible sense base, and it is also called the nourishing sense base.
Because it nourishes and enhances the other material dharmas.
Just as that which increases joy is called the sense base of joy.
Because it can nourish and nurture, it is called a nourishing place.
Venerable Vasumitra said:
Do the ultimate atoms mutually touch each other?
Answer: They do not mutually touch.
If they touched each other, they would then abide until the second moment.
The Venerable One said:
All ultimate atoms do not actually touch each other.
But based on the absence of an interval, the name touch is provisionally established.
There are those who say:
Ultimate atoms do not actually touch each other, nor are they without an interval.
But based on the mutual proximity of their aggregation, the name touch is provisionally established.
Question: The substance of the twelve sense bases is all dharmas.
Why is only one called the dharma sense base?
Answer: Although the substance of the twelve sense bases is all dharmas,
it is also without error to only establish one as the dharma sense base.
Because there is a simile.
Like the eighteen elements.
Although their substance is all dharmas,
only one is established as the dharma element.
Also, like the ten knowledges, although they all take dharmas as objects,
yet only one is given the name of dharma cognition.
Again, like the seven factors of awakening,
although they are all able to discern dharmas,
yet only one is given the name of factor of awakening that discerns dharmas.
Again, like the six recollections,
although they all take dharmas as objects,
yet only one is given the name of recollection of dharmas.
Again, like the four establishments of mindfulness,
although they all take dharmas as objects,
yet only one is given the name of establishment of mindfulness of dharmas.
Again, like the four forms of faith and understanding, although they all take dharmas as objects,
yet only one is given the name of faith and understanding of dharmas.
Again, like the four forms of unobstructed understanding, although they all take dharmas as objects,
yet only one is given the name of unobstructed understanding of dharmas.
Again, like the three jewels and three refuges, although their substance is all dharmas,
yet only one is given the name of jewel of the Dharma and refuge in the Dharma.
This is also like that. Although the substance of the twelve sense fields is all dharmas,
yet only one is given the name of sense field of dharmas. There is no error.
Furthermore, the sense field of dharmas has one name,
while the other sense fields have two names.
The first is the common name,
because the twelve sense bases are all dharmas.
The second is the common and uncommon name.
The common name is as above.
The uncommon name is the sense base of eyes, etc.
In order to make it easy to understand, the uncommon name is shown.
The sense base of dharmas has no uncommon name, so only the common name is shown.
Therefore it is called the sense base of dharmas.
Furthermore, the characteristic of birth of conditioned dharmas is only included in this sense base, so it is called the sense base of dharmas.
Furthermore, the four characteristics of conditioned dharmas are the seal, flag, and symbol of all dharmas.
They distinguish conditioned from unconditioned.
Those characteristics are only included in this sense base, so it is called the sense base of dharmas.

Furthermore, the aggregates of name, phrase, and syllable express, reveal, and make the nature and characteristics of dharmas easy to understand. Those three are only included in this sense base, so it is called the sense base of dharmas.
Furthermore, just as windows are called wind-passing places because wind passes through them,
the sense base of dharmas is also like this.
It is called the sense base of dharmas because it gives rise to all dharmas.
All afflictions, karma, samÄdhi, and wisdom, etc.
Are able to give rise to all conditioned dharmas.
And are able to realize unconditioned dharmas.
Furthermore, penetrating all dharmas as empty and non-self is the door of liberation of emptiness.
Because it is included in this realm, it is called the dharma realm.
Question: The view of the aggregates that grasps at all dharmas as self and what belongs to self is also included in this realm.
Why is this realm not called the self realm?
Answer: The view of the aggregates is a false grasping.
It does not accord with the true characteristics of dharmas and is understood.
Therefore, this realm is not established as the self realm.
The door of liberation of emptiness realizes the true characteristics of dharmas, and therefore this realm is named after it as the dharma realm.
Furthermore, cessation through discernment and nirvÄá¹‡a are permanent, wholesome, unchanging, and unalterable.
They are not destroyed by birth, old age, sickness, and death, and are the supreme truth.
Because those dharmas are only included in this realm, it alone is called the dharma realm.
Furthermore, discriminating the specific and general characteristics of dharmas,
It establishes the specific and common characteristics of all dharmas.
It destroys the ignorance of self-nature and the ignorance of objects, and the wisdom that understands non-increase and non-decrease of all dharmas as they really are.
Only this place is included, so it is called the dharma realm.
Other realms are not like this, so they are established separately.
Furthermore, this includes many dharmas, so it is called the dharma realm.
As for including many dharmas,
it means that in this realm there are form and formless dharmas,
associated and unassociated dharmas,ğŸ”½with support and without support dharmas,ğŸ”½with objects and without objects dharmas,
with aspects and without aspects dharmas,
with awareness and without awareness dharmas,
conditioned dharmas and unconditioned dharmas.
Other realms are not like this, so they are established separately.
Furthermore, this realm is called the dharma realm because it corresponds to the mind.
It means that the realms such as the eye only correspond to form, etc.
There is only the mental realm that corresponds to all dharmas.
Corresponding to the mind is the general name obtained separately.
For these various reasons, one of the twelve sense bases is called the dharma sense base.
Having explained the characteristics of each of the sense bases separately,
we should now further explain the sequence of the sense bases.
Question: Why did the World-Honored One first explain the internal sense bases and then the external sense bases?
Answer: Because he explained them in the sequence of the support and the supported by the six consciousnesses.
Question: Why did the World-Honored One first explain the eye sense base among the six internal sense bases,
and so on, up to the last explanation of the mind sense base?
Among the six external sense bases, why did he first explain the form sense base,
and so on, up to the last explanation of the dharma sense base?
Answer: Because it accords with the characteristics expressed by the literary expressions.
Furthermore, because it accords with the sequence of the Dharma that is explained, received, and upheld.
Furthermore, because it accords with the sequence of the Dharma that is coarse and fine.
That is to say, among the six internal sense bases, the eye sense base is the coarsest.
Therefore, it is explained first.
Up to the mind sense base being the finest.
Therefore, it is explained last. Among the six external sense bases, the form sense base is the coarsest.
Therefore, it is explained first.
up to the dharma realm, which is the most subtle, is therefore explained last.
Moreover, it is explained in the order of determined and undetermined.
Among the six internal sense bases, the first five definitely grasp present objects, so they are explained first.
The mental sense base grasps objects in an undetermined way, so it is explained last.
This means that it takes the dharmas of the three times and the unconditioned as objects,
either collectively or individually.
Among the first five sense bases, the first four definitely grasp derivative form, so they are explained first.
The body sense base grasps objects in an undetermined way, so it is explained last.
This means that it takes the primary elements and derivative form
as objects, either collectively or individually.
Among the first four sense bases, the one that takes objects that are distant, swift, and clear is explained first.
The one that is contrary to this is explained last.
The order of the six internal sense bases is explained in this way.
The order of the six external sense bases is also like this.
Moreover, it is explained in the order of the upper and lower sense bases.
In one body, the eye sense base is the highest.
The ear, nose, tongue, and body faculties are mostly located below.
The mind faculty has no specific location, so it is mentioned last.ğŸ”½The order of the six internal sense bases is explained in this way.
The order of the six external sense bases should be understood in the same way.
Moreover, this explanation is given based on the etiquette of sentient beings encountering each other.ğŸ”½When encountering each other,
they first see each other.
Next, they converse.
Next, they offer incense and flowers.
Next, they provide food and drink.
Finally, they give fine and exquisite bedding and other things.
Because of this, they mutually understand each other in the end.
The order of the twelve sense bases is like this.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
